[[Federation of Egyptian Trade Unions]] |international = |website = |colorcode = red }} The '''Workers National Democratic Party''' (WDP) ({{lang-ar|Ø­Ø²Ø¨ Ø§ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙÙØ·ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙÙØ±Ø§Ø·Ù}}) also ({{lang-ar|Ø­Ø²Ø¨ Ø§ÙØ¹ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØ·ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙÙØ±Ø§Ø·Ù}})is a [[workers' party|workers' political party]] in [[Egypt]] formed shortly after the [[Egyptian Revolution 2011|Egyptian Revolution]] of 2011.{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/04/20114221812915532.html | title=Empowering Egypt's workers revolution | publisher=Al Jazeera | date=25 April 2011 | accessdate=27 April 2011 }} It is backed by the [[Federation of Egyptian Trade Unions]]{{cite web | url=http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=24721 | title=Struggle and solidarity in the streets of Cairo | publisher=Socialist Worker (UK) | date=4 May 2011 | accessdate=5 May 2011}} and forms part of the [[Coalition of Socialist Forces]].{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/11968/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-leftist-front,-will-it-survive.aspx | title=Egypt's leftist front, will it survive? | publisher=Ahram Online | date=12 May 2011 | accessdate=18 May 2011 }} The party name is sometimes translated in English as '''Democratic Workers Party''', '''Democratic Labour Party''' or '''Labour Democratic Party'''. ==History== The party was initiated by the [[leftist]] front [[Hashd]] and the [[Revolutionary Socialists (Egypt)|Revolutionary Socialists]] (RS) in response to the country's growing [[Strike action|strike]] movement which [[2008 Egyptian general strike|preceded the revolution]]. WDP spokesperson [[Kamal Khalil]] says "Most leftist attempts to form a party include [[Intelligentsia|intellectual]]s as major players and a number of [[Proletariat|worker]]s as members... This party aims at having workers as the main players and leaders of the party joined by a number of intellectuals."{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/6863/Egypt/Politics-/January-Revolution-generates-a-new-Egyptian-politi.aspx | title=January Revolution generates a new Egyptian political map | publisher=Ahram Online | date=4 March 2011 | accessdate=27 April 2011 }} ==Politics== Although the RS have been instrumental in the formation of the party,{{cite web | url=http://socialistworker.org/2011/02/23/interview-with-egyptian-socialist | title=Conversation with an Egyptian socialist | publisher=Socialist Worker (US) | date=23 February 2011 | accessdate=28 April 2011 }}{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/05/20115910100577565.html | title=Breathless in Egypt | publisher=Al Jazeera | date=10 May 2011 | accessdate=11 May 2011 }} the WDP does not present itself as a [[vanguard party|revolutionary party]]. Party officials claim [[socialist revolution]] "is not feasible in the current political environment", citing the Egyptian [[proletariat|working class]]' "lack of political experience and the underdevelopment of the [[labour movement]]". They instead advocate the re-[[nationalization]] of industry and more genuine worker democracy.{{cite web | url=http://muftah.org/?p=1038 | title=Workers Struggle to Find Voice in Post-Mubarak Egypt | publisher=Muftah | date=25 March 2011 | accessdate=28 April 2011 }} Although not a self-proclaimed revolutionary party, the WDP cites revolutionary language and theory. For example, on [[May Day]], 2011 - the first May Day after Mubarak - the party chanted "A workersâ revolution against the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|capitalist government]]" while marching to [[Tahrir Square]].{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/11188/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-May-Day-celebrations-end-on-sour-note.aspx | title=Egypt's May Day celebrations end on sour note | publisher=Ahram Online | date=2 May 2011 | accessdate=11 May 2011 }} The same day, [[Hossam el-Hamalawy]], a representative of the party, called for "a complete halt to the [[Neoliberalism|neoliberal]] program."{{cite web | url=http://www.democracynow.org/2011/5/2/headlines/egypt_celebrates_international_workers_day_for_first_time_since_1952 | title=Egypt Celebrates International Workersâ Day for First Time Since 1952 | publisher=Democracy Now | date=2 May 2011 | accessdate=14 May 2011}} And [[Ahmed Ezzat]], one of the founders of the WDP has admitted "[[Vladimir Lenin|Lenin]]'s ''[[What Is to Be Done?|What is to be Done]]'' and ''[[April Theses|April Notes]]'' helped shape our strategy, as did [[Karl Marx|Marx]]'s theories". Ezzat has also labeled the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] "[[Counter-revolutionary|counter-revolutionaries]]". On 10 May 2011, the WDP agreed to enter into a "socialist front" with four other Egyptian leftist groups called the [[Coalition of Socialist Forces]]. The new grouping includes the [[Revolutionary Socialists]], the [[Egyptian Communist Party]], [[The Socialist Party of Egypt]] and the [[Popular Democratic Alliance Party]].{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/11855/Egypt/Politics-/Five-socialist-parties-unite-to-impact-Egyptian-po.aspx | title=Five socialist parties unite to impact Egyptian politics | publisher=Ahram Online | date=11 May 2011 | accessdate=18 May 2011 }} ==Demands== The partyâs most important principles are "the respect of all Egyptiansâ religious beliefs and bringing an end to discrimination on the basis of [[religion]], [[Race (classification of humans)|color]] or [[Gender|sex]]."{{cite web | url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/419823 | title=Establishment of new labor party announced at Tahrir Square | publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm | date=1 May 2011 | accessdate=23 May 2011 }} The re-nationalization of industry is one of the WDP's key demands but unlike under [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]], where the heads of state-owned factories were appointed by the [[President of Egypt|President]], the WDP calls on workers of these factories to appoint their own managers.{{cite web | url=http://bikyamasr.com/wordpress/?p=32778 | title=Fight for factories: Egyptâs textile workers challenge privatization | publisher=Bikya Masr | date=20 April 2011 | accessdate=5 May 2011 }} The WDP stands for abolishing [[privatization]] and [[monopoly]] policies, and redirecting development plans to benefit "underserved social classes".{{cite web | url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/egypt/workers-leftists-to-form-new-parties.html | title=Workers, leftists to form new parties | publisher=Daily News Egypt | date=28 February 2011 | accessdate=15 May 2011 }} The party is also coordinating with other forces to establish a higher [[minimum wage]] for Egyptian workers, the establishment of [[trade union]]s independent of the [[State (polity)|state]], and to improve working conditions in all workplaces. They are also calling for "combating administrative corruption and reevaluating Egyptâs economic ties to [[Israel]]".{{cite web | url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/401570 | title=Labor activists organize despite legal hurdles | publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm | date=15 April 2011 | accessdate=16 April 2011 }} Their slogan is "the workers must be united". ==Legality== Under the current [[Political Parties Law]], the WDP may not acquire official recognition, due to the law banning parties forming on a [[Social class|class]] basis. Also, party leaders are required to raise at least [[Egyptian pound|LE]]1 million to publish the names of at least 5000 founders in two widely-circulated [[Daily newspaper|dailies]]. The WDP sees this as the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] way of discriminating against the [[Poverty|poor]] and labour movement: "This shows that the old mentality is still there and that the government is siding with businessmen rather than workers." The WDP is expected to defy the legislation and launch their party as soon as they recruit at least 10,000 workers and 10,000 farmers.{{cite web | url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/418296 | title=Egyptâs workers: Between party politics and unionization | publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm | date=1 May 2011 | accessdate=5 May 2011 }} ==See also== * [[Workers' council]] * [[Vanguard party]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.facebook.com/pages/%D8%B5%D9%88%D8%AA-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B9%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%84/200680013291464 Official Facebook page of the Workers Democratic Party] (Arabic) {{Egyptian Revolution of 2011}} {{2010â2011 Middle East and North Africa protests}} {{Egyptian political parties}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Democratic Workers Party (Egypt)}} [[Category:2011 in Egypt]] [[Category:2011 riots]] [[Category:Activism]] [[Category:Anti-Zionism in Egypt]] [[Category:2011 Egyptian revolution]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2011]] [[Category:Political parties in Egypt]] [[Category:Politics of Egypt]] [[Category:Trade unions in Egypt]] [[Category:Protests in Egypt]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Egypt]] [[Category:Social democratic parties]] [[ar:Ø­Ø²Ø¨ Ø§ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙÙØ±Ø§Ø·Ù (ÙØµØ±)]]
